courses.title: Introduction to Computer Science
courses.info: CSCI 134 (Introduction to Computer Science) is traditionally the first course taken for the CS major. It is for students with little or no experience with computer science.

courses.title: Data Structures and Advanced Programming
courses.info: CSCI 136 (Data Structures and Advanced Programming) is traditionally the second course taken for the CS major.
courses.warning: CSCI 136 has CSCI 134 as a prerequisite.

courses.title: Discrete Mathematics
courses.info: Students must demonstrate proficiency in discrete mathematics by earning a grade of C- or better in MATH 200. Advanced mathematics students may replace MATH 200 with any of the following courses: MATH 328, MATH 334, MATH 341.

courses.title: Computer Organization
courses.info: CSCI 237 (Computer Organization) is a core course. Majors are encouraged to complete all core courses by the end of their junior year in order to ensure that they have the appropriate prerequisites for the electives.
courses.warning: CSCI 237 has CSCI 136 as a prerequisite.

courses.title: Algorithm Design and Analysis
courses.info: CSCI 256 (Algorithm Design and Analysis) is a core course. Majors are encouraged to complete all core courses by the end of their junior year in order to ensure that they have the appropriate prerequisites for the electives.
courses.warning: CSCI 256 has both CSCI 136 and CSCI 200 as prerequisites.

courses.title: Principles of Programming Languages/Theory of Computation
courses.info: You must take at least one of CSCI 334 or CSCI 361. Note that CSCI 256 is a prerequisite for CSCI 361.
courses.warning: CSCI 361 has CSCI 256 as a prerequisite.

courses.title: Math Elective
courses.info: This can be any Mathematics or Statistics course at the 200-level or higher, except for MATH 200.

courses.title: Computer Science Elective 1
courses.info: A course chosen from 300- or 400-level courses in Computer Science. Important note: Computer Science courses with 9 as the middle digit (reading, research, and thesis courses) normally cannot be used to satisfy the elective requirements.
courses.warning: Most electives have either 237 or 256 as a prerequisite.

courses.title: Computer Science Elective 2
courses.info: A course chosen from 300- or 400-level courses in Computer Science. Important note: Computer Science courses with 9 as the middle digit (reading, research, and thesis courses) normally cannot be used to satisfy the elective requirements.
courses.warning: Most electives have either 237 or 256 as a prerequisite.

courses.title: Computer Science Elective 3
courses.info: A course chosen from 300- or 400-level courses in Computer Science. Important note: Computer Science courses with 9 as the middle digit (reading, research, and thesis courses) normally cannot be used to satisfy the elective requirements.
courses.warning: Most electives have either 237 or 256 as a prerequisite.

courses.title: Computer Science Elective 4
courses.info: A course chosen from 300- or 400-level courses in Computer Science. Important note: Computer Science courses with 9 as the middle digit (reading, research, and thesis courses) normally cannot be used to satisfy the elective requirements.
courses.warning: Most electives have either 237 or 256 as a prerequisite.
